title: 109_s2670
content: The "Energy Fairness for America Act" is the short title of the Act, which amends the 1986 Internal Revenue Code. The table of contents for the Act is provided. The "Energy Fairness for America Act" amends the 1986 Internal Revenue Code by terminating deductions for intangible drilling and development costs, percentage depletion allowance for oil and gas wells, enhanced oil recovery credit, and certain provisions of the Energy Policy Act of 2005. It also includes revaluation of LIFO inventories, modifications of foreign tax credit rules, rules relating to foreign oil and gas income, and elimination of deferral for foreign oil and gas extraction income. The "Energy Fairness for America Act" terminates deductions for intangible drilling and development costs, percentage depletion allowance for oil and gas wells, and the enhanced oil recovery credit for taxable years beginning after the enactment of the Act. The Energy Fairness for America Act terminates the enhanced oil recovery credit for taxable years beginning after the enactment of the Act. The Energy Fairness for America Act repeals various provisions of the Energy Policy Act of 2005 related to oil and gas royalties, production incentives, and royalty relief. It also terminates the Alaska Offshore Royalty Suspension. The Energy Fairness for America Act repeals provisions related to oil and gas royalties, production incentives, and royalty relief. It also terminates the Alaska Offshore Royalty Suspension, with an effective date upon enactment of the Act. Termination of certain tax provisions of the Energy Policy Act of 2005. The Energy Fairness for America Act amends various sections related to electric transmission property, equipment used in refining liquid fuels, natural gas distribution lines, natural gas gathering lines, and the small refiner exception to oil depletion deduction. The Energy Fairness for America Act amends sections related to electric transmission property, refining equipment, natural gas distribution and gathering lines, and the small refiner exception to oil depletion deduction. Amendments include changes to the determination of the small refiner exception and the amortization of geological and geophysical expenditures. The effective date of these amendments is upon the enactment of the Act. Revaluation of LIFO inventories of large integrated oil companies is addressed in Section 7 of the Energy Fairness for America Act. The Energy Fairness for America Act addresses the revaluation of LIFO inventories for integrated oil companies. If a taxpayer is an applicable integrated oil company for its last taxable year ending in 2005, they must increase the value of historic LIFO layers of inventories of petroleum products and decrease the cost of goods sold. The layer adjustment amount is calculated based on the number of barrels of crude oil. The Energy Fairness for America Act requires integrated oil companies to adjust the value of historic LIFO layers of inventories of petroleum products based on the number of barrels of crude oil. This adjustment is not considered a change in accounting method and does not result in additional tax penalties for underpayments of estimated tax. The term "applicable integrated oil company" refers to an integrated oil company with specific production and revenue criteria. All persons treated as a single employer are considered one entity for tax purposes. SEC. 8. MODIFICATIONS OF FOREIGN TAX CREDIT RULES APPLICABLE TO DUAL CAPACITY TAXPAYERS. SEC. 8. MODIFICATIONS OF FOREIGN TAX CREDIT RULES APPLICABLE TO DUAL CAPACITY TAXPAYERS. Amends Section 901 by adding new rules for dual capacity taxpayers regarding taxes paid to foreign countries or possessions of the United States. The text discusses the modifications of foreign tax credit rules for dual capacity taxpayers, defining them as individuals subject to a levy of a foreign country or possession and receiving a specific economic benefit from that country or possession. It clarifies the treatment of income tax for such taxpayers. The amendments made by this section modify foreign tax credit rules for dual capacity taxpayers, defining generally applicable income tax as a tax imposed on income derived from a trade or business within a foreign country or possession. These changes apply to taxes paid or accrued in taxable years beginning after the enactment of this Act. The amendments made by this section apply to taxes paid or accrued in taxable years after the enactment of this Act, except where contrary to any U.S. treaty obligations. SEC. 9. RULES RELATING TO FOREIGN OIL AND GAS INCOME. The text discusses amending section 904(d) to include foreign oil and gas income in the separate basket for foreign tax credit before and after 2007. The definition of foreign oil and gas income is also clarified in the amendment. The amendment redesignates subparagraphs and clarifies the definition of foreign oil and gas income for foreign tax credit purposes before and after 2007. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years beginning after the enactment of the Act, with specific effective dates for years after 2006. Transitional rules apply to taxes paid or accrued before the enactment date related to income described in section 904(d)(1)(I) of the Code. The Act allows for the treatment of certain taxes paid on foreign oil and gas income as taxes paid or accrued. Unused oil and gas extraction taxes can be carried over to future taxable years. Losses related to the amendment are also addressed. The amendment made by subsection (c)(3) of section 904(c) does not apply to foreign oil and gas extraction losses from taxable years before the enactment of the Act. Elimination of deferral for foreign oil and gas extraction income. The amendment defines foreign oil and gas income as income related to foreign oil and gas extraction or foreign oil-related income. Conforming amendments replace "base company oil related income" with "oil and gas income" in various sections. The amendment changes the subsection heading and terminology from "Foreign Base Company Oil Related Income" to "Foreign Oil and Gas Income" in various sections. The effective date for these changes applies to taxable years of foreign corporations starting after the enactment of the Act.
